p: Avian retroviruses also remain potent pathogens in chickens, causing major losses in the poultry industry. A recent example is the outbreak of epidemics of hemangiomas and myelocytomas induced by subgroup J avian leukosis viruses in China. This subgroup of avian leukosis was first identified in 1991 in Britain [ 67, 68], but the significance of this finding has emerged only recently [ 69, 70, 71] as this virus is spreading world-wide [ 72, 73, 74]. The evolution of avian leukosis viruses is continuing, and new envelope subgroups are likely to emerge [ 75]. Since poultry is one of the main sources of animal protein, these viruses are of serious concern for the world food supply.
